turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: I've got it.  He bends down and bites the back of her neck.

turns.speaker: JUDY
turns.text: Oh! You're supposed to fasten it!

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: I feel like driving. Are you terrible hungry?

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: I told you. I have to go back into the past. Once more. For the last time.

turns.speaker: JUDY
turns.text: No, I don't want to go. I want to stay here.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: I can't do it alone. I need you, to be Madeleine for a while. Then, when it's done, we'll both be free.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: So am I, But it has to be done. I have to tell you about Madeleine, now.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: ...We stood there and I kissed her for the last time. And she said, "If lose me, you'll know that I loved you --

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: -- and wanted to go on loving you." And I said, "I won't lose you."  But I did.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: And I couldn't follow her.  God knows I tried.  One doesn't often get a second chance. I want to stop being haunted. You're my second chances, Judy.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: You look like Madeleine, now. Go up the stairs.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: Go up the stairs, Judy.  I'll follow.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: We're going up the tower, Madeleine.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: I'm going to. It's my second chance.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: But you knew, that day, that I wouldn't be able to follow you didn't you. Who was at the top when you got there? Elster? With his wife?

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: And she was the one who died. Not you.  The real wife.  You were the copy, you were the counterfeit. Was she dead or alive when you got there?

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: Took no chances, did he?  And when you got there, he pushed her off the tower, was that it? But you were the one who screamed. Why did you scream?

turns.speaker: JUDY
turns.text: I wanted to stop it, I ran up to stop it --

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: Why? Since you'd tricked me so well up to then?!! You played his wife so well, Judy! He made you over, didn't he? Just as I've done. But better! Not just the hair and the clothes! the look! the manner! the words! Those beautiful phony trances! That jump into the Bay! I'll bet you're really a strong swimmer, aren't you! Aren't you!!

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: Did he train you? Rehearse you? Teach you what to say and what to do?

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: And you were such an apt pupil! What fun you two must have had, playing games with me! Why me? Why did he pick on me?!!

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: Ah, yes! I was a set-up. I was the made-to-order witness. Where is he now?

turns.speaker: JUDY
turns.text: What are you going to do?

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: Look at the scene of the crime. Go on in.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: Oh, Judy!! When he had all her money, and the freedom and the power...  he ditched you? What a shame! But he knew he was safe. You couldn't talk. Didn't he give you anything?

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: And the necklace. Carlotta's necklace. That was your mistake, Judy. One shouldn't keep souvenirs of a killing. You shouldn't have been that sentimental.

turns.speaker: JUDY
turns.text: What are you going to do?

turns.speaker: JUDY
turns.text: I was safe when you found me, there was nothing you could prove! But when I saw you again I couldn't run away, I loved you so! I walked into danger and let you change me again because I loved you and wanted you!  Scottie, please! You love me now! Love me! Keep me safe!

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: Too late... too late... there's no bringing her back.

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: Why am I here? What happened?

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: Do you remember where you were?

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: Oh, of course I remember that!  But then I must have had a dizzy spell, and fainted!

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: ...Old Port Point!  Out at the Presidio! Of course I remember! I often go there!

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: Because I love it so. It's beautiful there. Especially at sunset.  Ah... thank you for the fire.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: Before?  Where?  Where had you been?

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: I will. You're terribly direct in your questions.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: I'm sorry. I didn't mean to be rude.

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: You're not. Merely direct. What were you doing there? At Old Fort Point?

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: The Palace of the Legion of honor. The Art Gallery.

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: Oh, that's a lovely spot, isn't it? I've never been inside. But it looks so lovely, driving past.

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: Lucky for me you were wandering about. Thank you again. I've been terrible bother to you.

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: When you...  There were pins in my hair...

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: You shouldn't have brought me here, you know.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: I... didn't know where you lived.

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: You could have looked in my car. Oh, but you didn't know my car, did you?

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: Yes, I knew which one it was. It's out there, now. But I didn't think you'd want to be brought home that way.

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: No, you are right,  I'm glad you didn't take me home... I wouldn't have known you, to thank you...  Oh, but I don't know you! And you don't know me! My name is Madeleine Elster.

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: That's a good, strong name. Do your friends call you John? Or Jack.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: John. Old friends. Acquaintances call me Scottie.

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: I shall call you Mr. Ferguson.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: No, I wouldn't like that. And after what happened today I should think you could call me Scottie. Or even John.

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: I prefer John. There, that's done.  And what do you do, John?

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: That's a good occupation. And live here... alone?

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: Will you tell me something? Has this ever happened to you before?

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: No, never before. I've fallen into lakes, out of rowboats, when I was a little girl. And I fell into a river, once, trying to leap from one stone to another. But I've never fallen into San Francisco Bay. Have you? Ever before?

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: No... this is the first time for me, too.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: Good morning. I worried about you, last night. You shouldn't have run like that.

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: I... suddenly felt such a fool.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: I wanted to drive you home. Are you all right?

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: Oh, yes. Fine. No after effects.  But as I remember now, that water was cold, wasn't it?  What a terrible thing to do... and you were so kind...  It's a formal thank-you letter. And a great big apology.

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: Oh, yes! The whole thing must have been so embarrassing for you!

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: I couldn't mail it; I didn't know your address. But I had a landmark. I remembered Coit Tower and it led me straight to you.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: The first time I've been grateful for Coit Tower.

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: No, I Just thought I'd wander.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: Ah.  That's what I was going to do.

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: Oh, yes, I forgot: It's your occupation, isn't it?

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: Don't you think it's sort of a waste for the two of us to...

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: Wander separately? Ah, but only one is a wanderer. Two, together, are always going somewhere.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: No... no, I don't think that's necessarily true.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: Do you know where you're going?

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: Of course not! I'm a wanderer!  I'd like to go somewhere I've never been!

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: If I've been there? That's silly! Either you've been to a place or you haven't.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: Oh... some, two thousand years, or more.

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: Of all the people who have been born... and have died... while the trees went on living.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: Their true name is Sequoia Sempervirens: always green, ever- living.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: Only silence. It's always like this.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: Would you like a drink of water?

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: Somewhere in here I was born... and here I died and it was only a moment for you... you took no notice...

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: Tell me what it is. Where do you go? What takes you away?

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: When you jumped in the bay, you didn't know where you were. You guessed but you didn't know.

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: I didn't jump, I fell! You told me I fell!

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: What was it inside that told you to jump?

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: No! Please! Please, please, please, please, don't ask me!

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: I'm responsible for you now, you know.  The Chinese say that once you have saved someone's life, you are responsible for it forever. And so I'm committed. And I have to know.

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: And you'll go on saving me? Again and again?

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: There is so little I know. It is as though I were walking down a long corridor that once was mirrored, and fragments of mirror still hang there, dark and shadowy, reflecting a dark image of me... and yet not me... someone else, in other clothes, of another time, doing things I have never done... but still me... And I can't stop to ask why, I must keep on walking. At the and of the corridor there is nothing but darkness, and I know when I walk into the darkness, I'll die.  But I've never come to the and; I've always come back, before then. Except once.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: But the small scenes, the fragments in the mirror: you remember them.

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: A room... there is a room, and I sit there alone... always alone...

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: I don't know. An open grave. I stand by the gravestone looking down into it. And it's my grave.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: There's a name on the gravestone.

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: No. It's new and clean, and waiting.

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: This part is dream, I think. There is a tower and a bell and... a garden below... but it seems to be in Spain... a village in Spain. And then it clicks off, and is gone.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: A portrait? Do you ever see a portrait?

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: Of the woman in the mirror. Would you know her if you saw her?

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: But I'm the woman in the mirror!

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: If I could find the key... find the beginning put it together...

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: And so explain it away?  But there is a way to explain it, you see. If I'm mad? That would explain it, wouldn't it?

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: I'm not mad. I'm not mad. And I don't want to die, but there's someone inside me, there's a somebody else, and she says I must die... Scottie, don't let me go!

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: I'm so afraid...  ...you won't let it happen...

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: Don't leave me... stay with me...

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: I should have phoned... but I wanted to see you... be with you...

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: I had the dream. The dream came back again...

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: I didn't wake him. I don't want him to know...

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: It was a dream, you're awake, you're all right, now. Can you tell me?

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: It was the tower again... and the bell, and the old Spanish village...

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: But clear... so very clear... for the first time... all of it...

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: There was a village square, a green with trees... and an old whitewashed Spanish church with a cloister. Across the green: a big, grey, wooden house with a porch and shutters and a balcony above... a small garden, and next to it, a livery stable... with old carriages lined up inside.

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: At the end of the green there was a whitewashed stone house with a lovely pepper tree at the corner --

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: -- and an old wooden hotel of the old California days, and a saloon... dark... low-ceilinged... with hanging oil lamps.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: It's all there. It's no dream.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: You've been there before. You've seen it.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: Madeleine, a hundred miles south of San Francisco there's an old Spanish Mission, Mission San Juan Bautista. It's been preserved exactly as it was a hundred years ago as a museum. Now, think hard, darling. You've been there before. You've seen it!

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: No, never! I've never been there! Scottie, what is it? I've never been there!

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: Go on with your dream. What was it that frightened you?

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: I stood alone on the green, searching for something, and I started to walk to the church. But then the darkness closed in, I was alone in the dark, being pulled into darkness, and I fought to wake up...

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: Not merely as it was a hundred years ago. As it was a year ago, or six months ago, whenever you were here to see it.  Madeleine, think of when you were here!

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: My love... because I love you.

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: I love you too... too late... too late...

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: Too late... there's something I must do...

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: There are things I have to tell you, about how we met, and why we are together. But they can wait. The only important thing now is that I love you and I'm going to keep you safe.

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: To the church, I must go there.

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: It's not fair, it's too late. It wasn't supposed to happen this way, it shouldn't have happened...!

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: It had to. We're in love. That's all that counts. Madeleine --

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: Let me go! Let me go!!

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: You believe that I love you?

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: And if you lose me, you'll know that I loved you and wanted to go on loving you.

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: Let me go into the church alone.

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: Please. Because I love you.  He stares at her, sees the pleading look in her eyes, and lets go. She turns and walks away toward the church, slowly, her head bowed. He watches her go and starts to move after her. Then slowly, as she goes, her head begins to go up until finally, as she walks, she is staring high above her.  And then, suddenly, she breaks into a broken run.

turns.speaker: MANAGERESS
turns.text: Is there something I can do for you?

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: Would you tell me, who has the room on the second floor in the corner, that corner?

turns.speaker: MANAGERESS
turns.text: Oh, I'm afraid we couldn't give out information of that sort. Our clients are entitled to their privacy, you know. And I do believe it's against the law! Of course, I don't think any of them would mind, really, but still I would have to know who you are, and ask --

turns.speaker: MANAGERESS
turns.text: Oh, dear! Has she done something wrong?

turns.speaker: MANAGERESS
turns.text: I can't imagine that sweet girl with that dear face --

turns.speaker: MANAGERESS
turns.text: Valdes. Miss Valdes.  It's Spanish, you know.

turns.speaker: MANAGERESS
turns.text: Yes, that's it. Sweet name, isn't it?  Foreign. But sweet.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: How long has she had the room?

turns.speaker: MANAGERESS
turns.text: Oh, it must be two weeks. Yes, the rent's due tomorrow.

turns.speaker: MANAGERESS
turns.text: No... she only comes to sit. Two or three times a week. And I never ask questions, you know. As long as they're well behaved. I must say that I've wondered --

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: When she comes down, don't say that I've been here.

turns.speaker: MANAGERESS
turns.text: Oh, but she hasn't been here today. Scottie whirls back on her.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: I saw her come in five minutes. ago.

turns.speaker: MANAGERESS
turns.text: Oh, no! She hasn't been here at all! I would have seen her, you know. I've been right here all the time, putting olive oil on my rubber plant leaves!

turns.speaker: MANAGERESS
turns.text: And there! There you see? Her key is on the rack!

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: Would you please go and look?

turns.speaker: MANAGERESS
turns.text: In her room? Well, yes, of course if you ask. But it does seem silly...

turns.speaker: MIDGE
turns.text: I thought you said no more aches and pains?

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: It's this darned corset. It binds. He retrieves the stick.

turns.speaker: MIDGE
turns.text: No three-way stretch? How very un- chic.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: Well, you know those police department doctors: no sense of style.  Ah, tomorrow!

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: Tomorrow... the corset comes off. And this thing goes out the window.  I shall be a free man. I shall wiggle my behind... free and unconfined.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: Midge, do you suppose many men wear corsets?

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: How do you know? Personal experience?

turns.speaker: MIDGE
turns.text: Please!  And what happens after tomorrow?

turns.speaker: MIDGE
turns.text: What are you going to do? Now that you've quit the police force?

turns.speaker: MIDGE
turns.text: No, it's your life. But you were the bright young lawyer who decided he was going to be chief of police some day.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: I wake up at night seeing him fall from the roof... and try to reach out for him.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: I know. I have Acrophobia. What a disease. A fear of heights. And what a moment to find out I had it.

turns.speaker: MIDGE
turns.text: Well, you've got it. And there's no losing it. And there's no one to blame. So why quit?

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: And sit behind a desk?  Chairborne?

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: Not with my Acrophobia, Midge. If I dropped a pencil on the floor and bent down to pick it up, it could be disastrous!

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: Nothing for a while. You forget, I'm a man of independent means. Or fairly independent.

turns.speaker: MIDGE
turns.text: Mmm. Why don't you go away for a while?

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: To forget? Don't be so motherly, Midge. I'm not going to crack up.

turns.speaker: MIDGE
turns.text: Have you had any dizzy spells this week?

turns.speaker: MIDGE
turns.text: It's a brassiere. You know about those things. You're a big boy, now.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: I've never run across one like that.

turns.speaker: MIDGE
turns.text: It's brand new. Revolutionary uplift. No shoulder straps, no back straps, but does everything a brassiere should do. It works on the principle of the cantilever bridge.

turns.speaker: MIDGE
turns.text: An aircraft engineer down the peninsula designed it. He worked it out in his spare time.

turns.speaker: MIDGE
turns.text: That's following a train of thought.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: Aren't you ever going to get married?

turns.speaker: MIDGE
turns.text: You know there's only one man in the world for me, Johnny-O.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: Yeah, I'm a brute. We were engaged once though, weren't we?

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: Ah, sweet college days. But you're the one who blew it. I'm still available. Available Ferguson. Say, Midge, do you remember a guy at college named Gavin Elster?

turns.speaker: MIDGE
turns.text: Gavin? Gavin Elster? You'd think I'd would. No.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: I got a call from him today. Funny. He dropped out of sight during the war, and I'd heard he'd gone East. I guess he's back.  It's a Mission number.

turns.speaker: MIDGE
turns.text: He's probably on the bum and wants to touch you for the price of a drink.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: Well, I'm on the bum; I'll buy him a couple of drinks and tell him my troubles. But not tonight. If you won't drink with me, I'll drink alone, tonight.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: Midge, what did you mean, there's no losing it?

turns.speaker: MIDGE
turns.text: I asked my doctor. He said only another emotional shock could do it, and probably wouldn't. And you're not going to go diving off another rooftop to find out.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: I think I can lick it.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: I've got a theory. Look. If I can get used to heights just a little at a time... progressively see?

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: Here, I'll show you what I mean. We'll start with this.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: What do you want me to start with -- the Golden Gate Bridge?

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: Now. I look up, I look down. I look up, I look down. Nothing to it.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: This is a cinch. I look up, I look down. I look up --

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: Oh, damn it! Damn it, damn it --

turns.speaker: MIDGE
turns.text: Now, that's the kind of greeting a girl likes.  None of this "hello you look wonderful" stuff. Just a good straight "who do you know" --

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: Well, who? Come on, you know everybody.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: Not that kind of history. The small stuff! About people you never heard of!

turns.speaker: MIDGE
turns.text: Oh!  You mean Gay Old Bohemian Days of Gay Old San Francisco!  The juicy stories? Like who shot who in the Embarcadero August, 1879?

turns.speaker: MIDGE
turns.text: Pop Leibel owns the Argosy Book Shop. What do you want to know?

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: Who shot who in the Embarcadero in August, 1879.

turns.speaker: MIDGE
turns.text: Wait a minute! You're not a detective any more. What's going on?

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: All right, come on. Introduce me. Where is your hat?

turns.speaker: MIDGE
turns.text: For bringing you here. Come on, tell!

turns.speaker: MIDGE
turns.text: You'll tell, or you'll be back in that corset! Come on!

turns.speaker: MIDGE
turns.text: Who's the guy, who's the wife?

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: Out. I've got things to do.

turns.speaker: MIDGE
turns.text: I know. The one who phoned. Your old college chum, Elster.

turns.speaker: MIDGE
turns.text: And the idea is that the Beautiful Mad Carlotta has come back from the dead, to take possession of Elster's wife?  Ah, Johnny! Come on!

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: I'm not telling you what I think! I'm telling you what he thinks!

turns.speaker: MIDGE
turns.text: Think?  Well, what do you think?

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: I did. Since when do you go about slipping notes under men's doors?

turns.speaker: MIDGE
turns.text: Since I stopped being able to get them on the phone. For a man who has nothing to do, you're certainly a busy little bee. Where do you go, these days?

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: What was this desperate urge to see me?

turns.speaker: MIDGE
turns.text: All I said in the note was: "Where are you?" That doesn't sound desperate to me.

turns.speaker: MIDGE
turns.text: I just thought if I gave you a drink and fed you some dinner, you'd be so grateful you'd take me to a movie.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: Fair enough. What'll we talk about at dinner?

turns.speaker: MIDGE
turns.text: If you want to. Naturally, we won't talk about anything you don't want to talk about.

turns.speaker: MIDGE
turns.text: Oh, I'm having a wonderful time! I've gone back to my first love... painting.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: Good. I've always said you were wasting your time in the underwear department.

turns.speaker: MIDGE
turns.text: Well, it's a living. But I'm excited about this.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: What is it, a still life?

turns.speaker: MIDGE
turns.text: No, not exactly. Want to see?

turns.speaker: MIDGE
turns.text: As a matter of fact, I thought I might give it to you.

turns.speaker: POP LEIBEL
turns.text: Yes... the Beautiful Carlotta... the Sad Carlotta...

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: What does a big old wooden house on the corner of Eddy and Gough Street have to do with her?

turns.speaker: POP LEIBEL
turns.text: It was hers. It was built for her. Many years ago.

turns.speaker: POP LEIBEL
turns.text: By... no... the name I do not remember. A rich man, a powerful man.  It is not an unusual story. She came from somewhere small, to the south of the city... some say from a mission settlement... young, yes; very young.  And she was found singing and dancing in a cabaret by the man... wait... wait... Ives! His name was Ives!  Yes. And he took her and built for her this great house in the Western Addition... and there was a child. Yes. This was it. The child.

turns.speaker: POP LEIBEL
turns.text: By her own hand.  There are many such stories.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: Thank you, Mr. Leibel. Thank you very much.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: No, that's not it. Nothing like it.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: Not tweed -- it's a smoother material, with a larger collar and belted.

turns.speaker: SALESWOMAN
turns.text: She'll be out in a moment.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: Now, Judy, it isn't anything to get --
